Award.AwardTitle: Assessing a Design Thinking Approach to APLU INCLUDES Summits
Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop on using design thinking for assessment and evaluation will advance the knowledge of the field in its understanding of ways to engage various stakeholder groups in using evaluative thinking from the beginning of an initiative. It specifically supports education and diversity through the audience of the Association of Public and Land-grant Universities (APLU) and the nature of the NSF INCLUDES context with its focus on broadening participation in the STEM enterprise (particularly higher education).

The scope is a workshop for approximately 100 APLU members to advance the use of evidence-based approaches to foster career pathways towards the professoriate by broadening participation pf underrepresented groups . The workshop will include plenary presentations, small group sessions and extensive opportunity for networking, reflection and consensus building.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Association of Public and Land-grant Universities (APLU) received funding to support to apply and assess a design thinking approach in both its 2017 and 2018 APLU INCLUDES Summits. Specifically, the funding allowed for a collaboration with The Value Web as professional facilitators who utilize a design-thinking approach for APLU's two annual INCLUDES Summits (April of 2017 & 2018).  The Summits were designed to leverage the content and context expertise of APLU's members and national partners and to engage participants in the collective impact of the NSF INCLUDES Design and Development Launch Pilot (NSF #1649214). 

The objectives of the Summit were two-fold: 1) to leverage the collective intelligence of APLU members and national partners regarding assessment, evaluation, and longer-term accountability; and, 2) test, iterate, and refine a design thinking and modeling concept?s impact upon the project?s collective impact approach. The summits were work-based and deployed design-thinking strategies to accelerate the rate at which participants understand the scope of the project and to assist key project leads as they developed implementation plans.  

The Value of Design-Thinking

Post-summit surveys demonstrated that participants believed they learned more from the use of design-thinking approaches (90% of respondents agreed or higher) but also described feeling more deeply engaged within APLU's network to address diversity and inclusion within STEM.

Post-Summit surveys were designed to measure:

  • What next steps were identified as a result of attending the summit;

  • The value of attending and knowledge gained;

  • The impact of design thinking on the agenda and ways of working; and,

  • What topics should be considered for future summits?

 

Key Results Included:

 

81%

of respondents felt able to address challenges faced in improving undergraduate STEM education as it applies to broadening participation to a Great to Some Extent

91%

of respondent felt able to address challenges faced in diversifying the professoriate to Great to Some Extent

90%

of respondents got new ideas that will be useful after the workshop to a Great to Some Extent

82%

of respondents were Very Likely to extend this discussion among colleagues at their institutions

65%

of respondents were Very Likely to review draft tools

55%

of respondents agreed they were better equipped to create or sustain change at their institution as a result of attending the summit

71%

of respondents agreed they were more committed to diversifying the STEM pathway as a result of attending the summit

71%

of respondents agreed they are more committed to diversifying STEM Faculty as a result of attending the summit

87%

of respondents agreed they developed new connections with colleagues in the field as a result of attending the summit

68%

of respondents agreed they strengthened connections with colleagues in the field as a result of attending the summit

75%

of respondents agreed they are better able to identify the challenges their institution is facing as a result of attending the summit

83%

of respondents plan on attending the next APLU INCLUDES Summit

"I really liked the design thinking format to engage more participant input and feedback." - Summit Participant

Respondents appreciate the design thinking approach for developing the agenda for critical issues in higher education. They would like to see more facilitation of networking opportunities to build community, encouraging of cross-institutional collaborations and partnerships, the curating of more success story examples and best practices, and finally, an articulated INCLUDES value proposition to start the conversation at their institutions.

"...it helped the assembled experience and expertise in the room to surface for the benefit of APLU, whose job it is to harness all of that and leverage it toward the project's goals. I felt like we were "free consultants" to APLU, but this is GOOD, because we all stand to benefit if you accomplish your goals. We also learned from each other." - Summit Participant

Respondents recognized design thinking allows for deeper conversations, more opportunities to co-creation solutions, encourages cross-institutional knowledge sharing, allows for a greater inclusion of perspectives and experiences, and fosters community building, most essential in any movement.
